Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: I sat at the edge of our bed, my partner’s hand trembling in mine. His eyes, red from sleepless nights, searched my face for comfort. He needed me—needed my words, my presence, my unwavering support as he faced the storm of his personal crisis. I wanted nothing more than to stay, to hold him, to reassure him that he wasn’t alone. But the bell from the chapel echoed through the halls, a reminder of my other life. Tonight, a special healing service was being held for Sister Agnes, who had fallen gravely ill. The community expected my presence, my prayers, my devotion. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my vows as a nun, my promises as a spouse. My heart ached as I looked from the door to my partner’s pleading eyes, torn between the sacred call of my faith and the desperate need of the person I loved most.
